act with compassion and always with honor and a sense of duty, though will often regret taking any action you fear would violate your code; even if they recognize such action as being good.
act altruistically, without regard for or against lawful precepts such as rules or tradition. You have no problems with cooperating with lawful officials, but does not feel beholden to them.

do what is necessary to bring about change for the better, disdains bureaucratic organizations that get in the way of social improvement, and places a high value on personal freedom, not only for oneself, but for others as well.
believe strongly in lawful concepts such as honor, order, rules, and tradition, but often follows a personal code in addition to, or even in preference to, one set down by a benevolent authority.

an individualist who follows your own heart and generally shirks rules and traditions. Although you promote the ideals of freedom, it is your own freedom that comes first; good and evil come second to your need to be free.
see a well-ordered system as being easier to exploit and shows a combination of desirable and undesirable traits.

selfish and have no qualms about turning on allies-of-the-moment, and usually make allies primarily to further your own goals. you have no compunctions about harming others to get what you want, but neither will you go out of your way to cause carnage or mayhem when you see no direct benefit for yourself.

tend to have no respect for rules, other people's lives, or anything but your own desires, which are typically selfish and cruel. You set a high value on personal freedom, but do not have much regard for the lives or freedom of other people. You do not work well in groups because you resent being given orders and do not usually behave yourself unless there is no alternative.
